Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: The missing anthropogenic N - assessing denitrification at the watershed scale
Award.AbstractNarration:
Lakes, estuaries, and coastal marine waters throughout the world have been degraded by over-enrichment with plant nutrients such as nitrogen (N) that cause algal blooms, and eventually deplete dissolved oxygen. Nitrogen exports to aquatic ecosystems have been increased by agricultural runoff, sewage discharges, and air pollution. Studies of these nitrogen sources have found less N exported by rivers than is expected from the amount of N added to the rivers by human activities. The N that does not enter rivers is either stored within the watersheds as soil or plant materials or converted to N gases by the microbial process of denitrification and lost to the atmosphere. The research supported by this award will involve development of new methods to improve measurements of gas fluxes from streams and soils to the atmosphere.

Building on previous research, this project will apply new methods to assess denitrification in agricultural watersheds. Denitrification consumes nitrate, the main form of N exported from N-enriched watersheds, and produces dinitrogen (N2) and nitrous oxide (N2O) gases. The project will measure accumulations of N2 and N2O gases in groundwater and soils, and changes in the isotopic composition of nitrate that are indicative of denitrification. The study will identify locations within watersheds where denitrification is hypothesized to have high rates, primarily in damp areas such as stream buffers and wetlands. The NSF-funded project will collaborate with a USDA-funded project in assisting farmers to select better agricultural practices by supplying information on areas with high denitrification potential for capturing N lost from croplands. Knowing the fate of agricultural N will help improve the management of the Choptank River watershed and other basins. The research efforts will also include participation of local high school, undergraduate, and graduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The world is awash in man-made nitrogen (N). We use fossil fuels to convert nitrogen gas (N2) in the air to ammonia (NH3) for fertilizer in a process called N fixation. Our motor vehicles are also a source of fixed N along with the soybeans and other legumes that we grow to feed ourselves and our animals. Globally, man-made fixed N is greater than natural N fixation by plants, lightning, and some algae.

What the scientific community does not fully understand is where all of the man-made fixed N goes. We are able to estimate how much fixed N enters a watershed, but when we compare this to the amount of N in the river or stream draining that watershed, only about 25% of the man-made N is measured. 75% of the originally input fixed N cannot be found, and we call this the “missing N.” Because we know how much N is entering and leaving the watersheds, the missing N is either stored in soils or plants within the watersheds, or it is biologically converted back to N2 gas in a process called “denitrification.” Once the fixed N is converted to N2 within the watershed, it escapes back to the atmosphere, completing the N cycle. Unfortunately, both N storage and N2 gas losses to the atmosphere are difficult to measure within a watershed because the amount stored and the rate of N gas loss changes substantially over large land areas. Nonetheless, it is important to understand the fate of man-made fixed N because the degradation of coastal waters, such as the Chesapeake Bay and the Gulf of Mexico, is now being caused by only 25% of the man-made N added to our land.

In our NSF-funded research we focused on the accumulation of excess N2 gas in groundwater, soils, and streams. In groundwater and streams, we used an existing method for measuring the ratio of dissolved N2 gas relative to argon (Ar), a noble gas which is biologically unreactive. In both groundwater and stream waters we found large excesses of N2 gas (N2/Ar greater than the atmospheric ratio), indicative of large amounts of denitrification. This biological process can occur within groundwater or in the stream bed as groundwater enters the stream, usually where dissolved oxygen (O2) is low.

We also developed two new methods in our research project. One method is for measuring the movement of N2 gas from streams to the atmosphere using another noble gas, radon.  Radon is typically known to the public as a hazard in basements, but radon proved useful as a natural tracer for gas fluxes to the atmosphere from streams. The second method was an extension of the N2/Ar measurements in water to measure N2/Ar in air. This was a difficult task as there are many more molecules of N2 and Ar in air than there are dissolved in water. However, we have been able to detect relatively small changes in the N2/Ar of soil air, and we developed a model that predicts the physical effects on the N2/Ar from groundwater temperature changes. The available data support the idea that denitrification is widespread in watersheds.

We have not found all of the missing N. We developed methods to look for excess N2 from denitrification, and we found it virtually everywhere that we looked. However, we still need to use these methods more widely throughout a watershed where we know how much man-made N is being applied. We will have to overcome the differences in soil and stream characteristics over large land areas by smart sampling in order to estimate N2 loss from denitrification relative to the missing N. This will be the subject of a future research project.
